instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PWRBTN_L: What is PWRBTN_L? PWRBTN_L Is an abbreviation of PM_PWRBTN_L which refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
I was trying to solder back a broken speaker/mic connector last night and after finishing that job I found that the board would no longer power up. It's been a faithful companion to me since I bought it in 2009 so I would rather not give up on this one ...

All G3H rails are present save for <SIGNAL>PP18V5_G3H</SIGNAL> which is reading only 17.13v rather than the expected 18.5v. I'm not getting anything on the S5 rails.

I was using an iron only with the exception of maybe a few seconds of warmth (180C) to evaporate some alcohol.

If I had to guess, I'd say the culprit is <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.  Any thoughts on how to back up the guess or investigate other things?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage? <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: 12.56v on ppbus g3h and 0v on <SIGNAL>SV3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> present? If yes then check around the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>, check for shorts on the outputs first.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
The en lines into <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> were both at 3.3v.  But the 5v outputs where at zero.  I've taken it off the board for the time being. 

will test <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> in the morning.  Thanks.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: I hope you did not power the board without <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> as this can totally fry everything!!!

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
nope! 

Replaced the chip this morning, and some resistors that blew off the board during removal.  I didn't have the right value replacement for  <RESISTOR>R7271</RESISTOR>.  It's rated at 86.6k (1%) and may effectively create a voltage divider from the internal resistance to the  drain of the n-channel mosfet (<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>). 

After replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>), I've got the 5v rail back, the g3h lines are as above and the <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> signal was 3.3v.  

no spin-up still though!  I didn't have time to probe further this morning but would appreciate any direction for next steps.  

thanks
Justin

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: Make sure you use the power on pads they donâ€™t auto start this old

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Thanks John.  Yes - not expecting modern magic!  I was using the debug pads but nothing doing.  Just in case I had the wrong pads, I reassembled the laptop but I'm still getting no spin-up.  

I'd be really grateful for advice on what next to check.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: Which 5V rail is back? Is there 3V on L7220 and 5V on L7260 when you power on?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Parts now arrived for this and I have replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> with a new chip .

Still no spin up and I will test the power rails later.  Getting a green light and I was getting the orange light.  No longer but this could well be that the battery is charged .

I did notice that the battery indicator cable is shredded though.  In two bits so no continuity on any pins. No shorts though (having unplugged it).

Is this indicator assembly critical to operation?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: BIL is not needed. Orange light will not come on if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not present so I think you may have created an issue there.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
this board is back on the bench after the summer break.  It's from my favourite workhorse of the last 9 years, so I'm keen to revive it. 

brief recap: 

board was working fine until I soldered the speakers back on to the board (the connector had ripped off years before).  I must have knocked or damaged <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

New <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on the board (second new one, just in case).
PPBUS and PP3v42 are present
no s5 rails.  

<SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is at 3.4v.

<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG3</SIGNAL> is at 3.3v

[LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px]<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG5</SIGNAL> is at 5v.[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

15mv on L7220
8mv on L7260

on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> I get the following


1.  15mv
2. 15mv
3.  2.00v 
4. 3.3v
5.  8mv
6.  0.75v

7. 13mv
8.  3.3v
9.  4.55v
10. 15mv
11. 15mv
12. 12.5mv

13. 3.37v
14. 2.0v
15. gnd
16. 12.57v
17. 5.01v
18. 

19. 12mv
20. 10mv
21. 12mv
22. 4.55v
23. 10mv
24.  8mv

on <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR> I have 3.4 at <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> (as above) and close to zero on <SIGNAL>PM_G2_P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>.  

on <TRANSISTOR>Q7280</TRANSISTOR> I get a few mv on <SIGNAL>5V_S3_LL</SIGNAL> and pulsing from 300mv to 1.1v on <SIGNAL>5V_S3_HH</SIGNAL>



all helpful pointers greatly appreciated!  thanks
Justin

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is correctly powered up and it has <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power supply enabled.
You should now have 3V3 at L7220.
If not, check for short/low resistance there.
Also check if <CAPACITOR>C7220</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7269</RESISTOR>/70 are OK.

Don't forget to check all traces around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
yes - I do have 3v3 at L7220! and the 1v05 s5 rail as well. that's really odd: I could swear that they were not there when I last tested - I wonder whether the board needed to be turned on to have the s5 rails and somehow I failed to touch the contacts correctly?

anyway - great news. Now to find out why the s3 rails aren't present?  It doesn't help that the schematic I have seems to be incorrect (no <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on it..., but it does have <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>).

On a related subject is there anyway to _guarantee_ that the right power up signal has been sent to this board? I don't think that there's any point in chasing the S3 rail without guaranteeing that the SMC is being properly told to start up.

Thanks!

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: Hello   no luck getting the s3 rails up.  seemingly the 3v3 and 5v <SIGNAL>S3_EN</SIGNAL> lines come from the MCP and neither are high.  also <SIGNAL>PM_RSM_RST_L</SIGNAL> is not going low.    any suggestions for getting over this next hurdle are very welcome.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Why would you want <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> to go low?
How will then MCP work with active reset signal ???

This board doesn't turn on by itself; momentarly short power pads <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>/16.
Does the <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> react then?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Thanks

I wrongly assumed that active low in this case meant that the signal would pulse low and reset the MCP for turning on. 

The <SIGNAL>PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> signal drops to 170mV or so when the pads are shorted.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
So it drops 3V-0-3V?
That means SMC send the power button info to MCP.
This one should respond puting high the sleep signals, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>.
Look at page 66, Power Control Signals...

Do these signals pulse at least?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
I have not got an oscilloscope but on a multimeter the pmslps4l (which becomes <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL>) stays low .  This signal feeds the S3 en signal for the 3v3 rail too .

Bust mcp then.  

Which is bizarre as all this happened when I was working on the audio connectors with the board disassembled .

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
If you work close to 3/5V power supply, check for any knocked off component, or damaged trace.
Pay atention for enabling signals...

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
the only major chip that was close by to where I was working was the s5 regulator (<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>).  and even that was a good 15-20mm from the area of the audio connector. 

the <SIGNAL>S3_EN</SIGNAL> signals come directly from the MCP though.  So unless someone has a better idea I fear somehow that the MCP has fried.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is close too.
And it has few components connected on the opposite side; related with enable signal...

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: true.  I replaced that with the TPS though !

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Hi again

I'm getting only 22Ohm to ground on pin 1 of L7260.  has anyone got an equivalent board they can test for me to see what's normal?  injecting voltage there I get some high(ish) heat on the L3405 and <CAPACITOR>C3452</CAPACITOR> pair.  and some heat on the two inductors l3402 and l3403.  I will remove <CAPACITOR>C3452</CAPACITOR> in the morning to see what difference that would make, but I'd expect closer to zero ohms for a real short to ground.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
I'm really getting confused by this.  I suspect it is in large part because the schematic does not line up at all with the boardview files I have.  I'm using drawing number 051-7546 in case that helps anyone ?

on the boardview, the pin that has the low resistance is pin 1 of L7260.  On the schematic, pin 1 is connected

directly to <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> (labelled as <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> on the schematic and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on the boardview) to the <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_LL</SIGNAL> pin
indirectly via an RC pair <RESISTOR>R7264</RESISTOR>/<CAPACITOR>C7264</CAPACITOR> to <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VBST</SIGNAL>
and into <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>.  

the low resistance to ground remains there even when <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> AND the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> are removed.  


On the boardview, pin 1 is connected to all sorts of things.  So it looks like the pin numbers are inverted. 

Is this is a known issue with the generally available boardview/schematic pairs?  I'm feeling it is not worth the time to chase a rabbit down a hole when the map of the burrow is incorrect ...

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
Harrumph ... 

i have found a schematic that corresponds to the boardview now.  i will trace from pin 1 of l7260 and see what i find before posting back again. 

thanks

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
L7260 is a short in DC, like any other coil.
I suppose the low value is on L7260 pin2.
Lift one side of the coil and see where the low value remains...

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
if course - as per the above, the short is on the side of pin 1.  I've lifted so far the RTC, <TRANSISTOR>Q7940</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, L3405, <CHIP>U4800</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7291</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7290</CAPACITOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q4590</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q3450</TRANSISTOR> and tested the resistors and other caps in the area.  the low resistance remains.

Lifting  resistor <RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR> tells me that the problem is on the  pin 1 side of that.

But nothing looks bad or burned on the board.  No corrosion and, as I said, it was working fine until I 'fixed' the speaker connector just north of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.  Evidently I've blown something downstream, but with 20Ohms it's unlikely to generate that much heat to be able to trace it.

When I'm next at the bench I will life <CHIP>U6200</CHIP> just in case that is the culprit.

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message: removing <CHIP>U6620</CHIP> increased the resistance to 50Ohm.  may be worth removing <CHIP>U6630</CHIP> as well.  Perhaps I blew the audio amps?

threads.title: Macbook 2009 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no spin-up
threads.message:
and removing <CHIP>U6620</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6610</CHIP> resolved the short.  resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is now 3.8k or so.  

hopefully that resolves the power issue generally.  I will have time to test properly this evening (fingers crossed)
